title: (x) Willesden Public Library serif book face - Garamond No. 3 {Gary Long, Max Rabkin}
content:
I'm reading an autobiography set in this face, and I find it really distracting -- not nearly as invisible as a book face should be -- because in my eyes the lc _d_ and _p_ are well below the x-height. It isn't that noticeable in this scan (possibly because it's bigger on screen).

Anyway, I'd like to know what it is.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013174124im_/http:/typophile.com/files/uncle-tungsten-serif.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [uncle-tungsten-serif.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013174124/http:/typophile.com/files/uncle-tungsten-serif.jpg) | 15.11 KB |
author: mr

comments.content: Is it ITC Garamond? Hard to tell at that small size.

No that's not a match, in ITC Gar actually the b and d look too large. But it looks like a Garamond...

Ah... it's DT Garamond

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/dtptypes/garamond-dt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013174124/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dtptypes/garamond-dt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/dtptypes/garamond-dt/")
At least we’ve narrowed it down to the myriad Garamonds that exist! ;^)

Nice one Patty.

That’s a pretty nasty looking italic.
It's a Garamond that wishes it were a Caslon.

Garamond No 3 is very similar (maybe the same thing under another name?). I believe it's based on Jannon, not the original Garamond. Personally, I like it as a book face. It's slight quirkiness gives it a warmth suitable for certain topics.
I think Garamond No 3 is closer than the DT (the "crook" of the _g_ is sharper, and the serifs on the _d_ slope down less) but I'm still a type ID newbie.
